content_1: . According to a health official, 2,000 chickens have died in Jambi provinceover the past month and bird flu remains a threat. The disease has spread to nearly all of the districts and towns in the province and 50% more chickens have died from bird flu than in February of 2009. The head of the province`s animal husbandry office, Hanis Lubis, said on March 12 that this increase was likely caused by a longer rainy season and the local breeders’ habit of throwing dead chickens into rivers instead of burning them. Most of the chickens that have died belonged to local residents, but there have been no reports of human infection so far. Veterinarians have been deployed to infected areas to improve public awareness of the disease and Lubis urges citizens to immediately inform the animal husbandry office if they find large numbers of chickens that have suddenly died. Bird flu remains a problem in all provinces of Indonesia especially during the rainy season.
content_2: . The District Livestock Service Office (DLO) of Nawalparasi announced on March 17 that bird flu has been detected in several Village Development Committees. The district has been declared an emergency zone. After ducks and chickens in the district began to die, the DLO sent samples to Britain for testing. It is reported that many birds have died recently and that residents are afraid that bird flu might spread rapidly because of the improper disposal of dead birds.
content_3: . Romania’s national laboratory confirmed an outbreak of H5N1 bird flu on a backyard poultry farm in Letea, on the Danube delta. Romania undertook the measures specified under European Union legislation to prevent the spread of the disease, including culling the poultry on the infected farm, establishing a protection zone within a 3 km radius, establishing a surveillance zone within a 10 km radius, banning the gathering of poultry, and strengthening biosecurity measures. This is the first outbreak of bird flu in the European Union in over a year.
content_4: . On March 14, the Bac Ninh provincial People’s Committee announced the occurrence of bird flu in Nam Son commune. 400 birds on a farm began to show signs of illness on March 10 and died on March 11. The birds had been vaccinated for four months. The veterinary agency inspected the farm and found signs of bird flu so they destroyed the remaining birds on the farm and sent samples to a central veterinary diagnostic centre, and had the area disinfected with lime and cloramin B. The Bac Ninh Animal Health Department has set up two temporary checkpoints, suspended all activities involving poultry in markets within Nam Son commune, vaccinated all the fowl in the commune, and is closely monitoring the slaughter of poultry in an effort to prevent the disease from spreading.
content_5: . The Ministry of Health announced two new cases of H5N1 bird flu infection in humans on March 12. The first case is a pregnant, 20-year-old woman from Qalyubiyah governorate.  She was hospitalized on March 5, treated with oseltamivir, and died on March 9. The second case is a 1 1/2 year old boy from Kafr el Sheik governorate, who was hospitalized on March 2, treated with oseltamivir, and is in stable condition. Investigations into the cause of infection suggest that both patients had been exposed to sick and dead poultry. The Egyptian Central Public Health Laboratories confirmed H5N1 bird flu as the cause of illness in both cases. The ministry also reported the death of a 53-year-old man from Qalioba governorate who had developed symptoms of bird flu on February 27. Across Egypt to date there have been 106 confirmed cases of H5N1 bird flu in humans and 32 fatalities.
content_6:
. According to the Ministry of Health, a 25-year-old woman in Ha Noi tested positive for H5N1 bird flu on March 11. The patient allegedly caught the disease from dead and ill poultry near her home and is now in intensive care at Bach Mai General Hospital.  A 3-year-old girl who was infected with H5N1 bird flu died on March 17.. The child was admitted to Children’s Hospital No.2 on March 10 with suspected dengue fever, but developed pneumonia and tested positive for bird flu on March 15. Her condition worsened and she died early on Wednesday. Doctors say that her family lived near a market where chickens were sold.  This is the 59th death from bird flu in Vietnam since 2003 and the second death from bird flu in 2010
